column4: fabs is in math.h if i'm not mistaken, so i don't see why it shouldn't be available if you have build-essential. and if you didn't have math.h, well it would tell you...
yeah, I've got math.h via build-essential on both.

i suspected you did... now, the only things i can think of is either 1) it's not really the same program that you're compiling or 2) your RAM, or other hardware, is bad, and GCC is known to often make RAM errors quite visible
I've made sure I downloaded the same archive onto both machines.
dunno, write a .c test file with #include <math.h>, int main() { printf("%f\n", fabs(10.3)) }, and compile with gcc -lm. at least you'll see if there's actually a problem with fabs
as for the RAM, I doubt that it is bad. The machine runs rock-solid with everything else.
will try that, thanks

well anyway tgmath.h shouldn't *have* to be included manually, math.h is enough to get fabs(). to make sure the installations are both valid, you could also try "debsums". and i would also try diffing dpkg --get-selections, not just with -dev...
also if you *really* want to make sure the installations are the same... try something like find -xdev / | xargs -n 1 md5sum >machine1 - same on machine2, and diff the two ;)
I'm having trouble with your sample program, too... Can we meet in #ubuntu-classroom?
I found a solution to my earlier problem...
won't that fill the file up until the disk is full?
no. Note it's /dev/null, not /dev/zero
what was it?
oh, /dev/null right... never used it for input
the program depended on libfltk-dev, which also comes with a math.h. Now I was giving the wrong include path, /usr/include/FL, when I should just have given it /usr/include
you as in manually? you had to give the include path manually?
yes, in the cmake config. It didn't find it spontaneously.
weird though because /usr/include is the *default* include path... if you call gcc without any options at all, it'll just use that
but then i've seen weirder build systems *shrug*
thanks again for your pointer in the right direction.
